awd_titl_txt: Tissue-Specific Expression of Cytochrome c Oxidase
awd_abstract_narration: Mammalian cytochrome c oxidase (COX) consists of 13 subunits:                   three encoded in mitochondrial DNA and 10 in nuclear DNA.  Long-                term goals are to understand the regulation of this critically                  important enzyme complex through analysis of the genetic regulatory             sequences controlling expression of COX nuclear genes.  Short term              goals include defining the cis-regulatory sequence elements (cis-               elements) in the promoters of two COX genes:  human COX5B (for a                ubiquitous subunit VB), and bovine COX8H (for subunit VIII-heart).              They will:  (1) identify by DNA sequencing those cis-elements in                the promoter of the COX5B gene known to be important for                        transcriptional control of other genes; (2) identify unique cis-                elements important for transcriptional control of respiratory genes             by functional analysis of the COX5B promoter through a) analysis                of DNAseI hypersensitive sites, b) gene fusion experiments, and C)              transient expression studies; (3) clone and sequence the promoter               of the bovine COX8H gene to identify unique cis-elements important              for tissue-specific expression.  These studies on the cis-                      regulatory sequence elements controlling expression of nuclear                  genes for this unique enzyme complex will contribute to our                     understanding of the genetic regulatory signals involved in                     mitochondrial biogenesis and in tissue=specific expression of this              important enzyme complex.*** //
